title: On the scene in Tunisia: 'People were shouting, swearing and arguing – and nobody knew what was happening.'
text:
Save 
Daniel Hoggan, one of TTG’s 30 under 30, was staying at a nearby hotel when the terrorist attack took place. Here he describes the day’s events. 
By chance, we went on an excursion on Friday, otherwise my girlfriend and I would have been on that beach ourselves. 
We got back to our hotel at about 4.30pm and the hotel was on lockdown. 
People in the UK seemed to be getting more news than we were. Given the information that there might be a second gunman on the run, people had barricaded themselves into their rooms. 
It was chaotic in the hotel reception. People were shouting, swearing and arguing – and nobody knew what was happening. 
There were two reps from Thomson and First Choice, but with such high tensions, it was hard for them to handle. 
We were told it was a mandatory evacuation and we queued to give our names for flights home. 
A Tui crisis team arrived from Hanover on Saturday evening, telling us evacuation was not mandatory and that we could stay. 
Some guests decided to, but we felt it was no longer a “holiday”, sitting on the beach just 10 metres from where people had been killed. 
We were asked to stay in our room and wait for flight information. At 5.30pm on Sunday, we were given 10 minutes to get on the coach. We then stopped at the attacked hotels and drove straight in – I was surprised there wasn’t more security. 
Tui said it would refund us for our holiday from Friday – nine days’ worth. But because so many people are changing their plans, everywhere is fully booked or too expensive, so we will postpone rebooking until later this year. 
We initially had a wonderful holiday. Tunisia is a nice place. I hope it can recover. 
Daniel Hoggan of digital agency Mediaworks is one of TTG ’s Tomorrow’s Travel Leaders and was on a Thomson holiday at Royal Kenz Hotel, neighbouring the two targeted Riu properties
